clinical_study.brief_title: Determinants of Cardiovascular Disease Risk Factors Among Youth With Type 1 Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: Early Myocardial Morphologic and Functional Changes and Their Association With Diet and Physical Activity in Adolescents With Type 1 Diabetes

brief_summary.textblock: Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1D) is the most common form of diabetes among children and youth, and it is increasing around the world, particularly among children under 5 years. This is worrisome given the chronic nature of the disease and its strong association with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD). Evidence suggests that markers of CVD are already present in children with T1D, making prevention a clinical and public health priority in this high-risk population. Despite this, a good understanding of what factors predispose children with T1D to CVD is still lacking. Our study aims to better understand in this population what individual and familial characteristics increase the risk for heart disease, how to best measure it early on and what are the potential mechanisms underlying the heightened risk for heart disease in youth with T1D. Specifically, we aim to: 1) better understand how physical activity and sedentary behavior are associated with early markers of CVD in children with T1D; 2) better understand how inflammation and insulin resistance are associated with early markers of CVD in children with T1D; 3) determine if insulin resistance explains the association between lifestyle habits and early markers of CVD in this population. To achieve these objectives, we will evaluate the presence of cardiovascular disease (CVD) markers, including established (dyslipidemia, hypertension) and novel (cardiac structure, endothelial function, myocardial oxygenation) markers in 100 adolescents with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and 100 healthy controls, and compare associations of lifestyle habits (physical activity, diet, sedentariness, sleep) with CVD markers across both groups. Our study provides an exceptional opportunity to increase our knowledge on what factors predispose children with T1D to cardiovascular disease. Understanding the interplay between T1D, lifestyle habits and metabolic markers and CVD is critical to developing effective prevention strategies for these vulnerable children.

arm_group.description: Girls and boys aged 14-18 years old, living with Type 1 Diabetes.
Age and sex matched adolescents without any type of diabetes

study_pop.textblock:
T1D group: Sainte-Justine Hospital's Diabetes Clinic patients
Control group: Community sample

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of T1D (for the T1D group) or no diagnosis of any type of diabetes (for the control group)
- 14 to 18 years old
Exclusion Criteria:
- Youth with another type of diabetes such as T2D
- Conditions that could limit their ability to participate in the study
- Known pathology that would influence their risk for CVD
- Siblings of a participant already enrolled in the study
